entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - SUM of Subtotals is not matching the Total
entry.content:
Hi all,

I'm building a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) using a live connection to an SAP HANA view. I have an issue that when results are presented for multiple Org Units the SUM of the Subtotals (for each Org Unit) is not matching the overall Totals (for all Org Units). 

The underlying data model contains daily records that could be simplified into these fields:

  • Date (attribute)
  • FTE (measure ‚Äì stable over time)
  • Quota (measure ‚Äì may change daily)
  • Org Unit (attribute with hierarchy)

If an Org. Unit doesn't have a Quota value for a specific day, there is no record at all for that day and the row is missing (not NULL or 0).

In SAC model I have added date hierarchy (Year-Quarter-Month) based on the Date field and created a calculated measure TotalFTE = FTE * Quota to display the TotalFTE month by month on the dashboard.

However, when aggregating TotalFTE by Org Unit at the daily level, I found that Org Units with incomplete daily records had inconsistent results as their denominator was not matching denominator of Org Units with complete daily records.

For example:

  • If Org Unit A had had records for only 15 days in a 30-day month the denominator was 15: TotalFTE(Subtotal A) = FTE*Quota/15.
  • Org. Unit B with complete records for the whole month (30 days) had the denominator as 30: TotalFTE(Subtotal B)=FTE*Quota/30.

This then resulted that the SUM of Subtotals (Subtotal A + Subtotal B) were not matching the Totals: TotalFTE(A+B)=FTE(A+B)*Quota(A+B)/30, as the denominators were not the same.

When trying to fix this, I enhanced the HANA view to include:

  • A Month column (derived from Date)
  • A CountMonthDays field (the number of calendar days in each month, e.g. 31 for March)

I then updated the SAC formula to normalize against the number of days in the month: TotalFTE = FTE * Quota / CountMonthDays to have the same denominator.

This worked well at the monthly level ‚Äî Subtotals and Totals aligned correctly.

However, the problem reappears when:

  • Aggregating by Quarter or Year
  • Users apply filters for custom time ranges (e.g. Jan‚ÄìMay)

Since some Org Units don‚Äôt have records for every Month in the selected period, their TotalFTE is divided by fewer days due missing months (e.g. only 90 instead of 151), while the total uses the full range (e.g., 151 days), causing Subtotals ‚â† Totals again.

Thanks in advance for any ideas or experience with this issue!

entry.title: Why are dimension attributes not available in Calculated Dimensions in a SAC Story?
entry.content:
Problem Statement

We are using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with a live connection to an Analytic Model (AM) created on top of a Fact Table  in SAP Datasphere.

We observed that:

  • When trying to create Calculated Dimensions within the SAC , only keys and columns from the Fact Table are available.
  • Attributes from associated Dimension Tables are not visible for use in formula expressions inside Calculated Dimensions.
  • However, those same attributes can be displayed in SAC stories without issue.

In below example only keys and dimension attributes from FACT are available and not all the attributes from the Dimension tables joined with FACT -

 

Question:

Why are dimension attributes (from Dimension Tables joined with FACT) not available in Calculated Dimensions, even though they appear in the SAC story view?

In my opinion, this behavior is due to the live connection architecture and how SAC interprets model metadata from Datasphere:

  1. SAC only allows calculated logic (e.g., Calculated Dimensions) to reference fields that are part of the Analytic Model schema.

  2. When the AM is built directly on a Fact Table/View, it only includes the foreign keys, not the descriptive attributes of related dimensions.

  3. In a live connection, SAC pushes all calculation logic to Datasphere, so fields must be explicitly present in the underlying dataset or view for them to be available in formulas.

To make dimension attributes available in Calculated Dimensions within SAC, we have used Graphical Views with Explicit Joins

  • In Datasphere, created a Graphical View where we joined the dimension tables to the Fact Table using foreign keys.

  • This exposed both keys and attributes in the resulting Analytic Model, making them available in SAC for both display and calculations.
  • With this approach we can see all the attributes also from Dimension Tables/Views in a Calculated Dimension Formula.

 

 

Is this the correct approach? or is there alternative approach?

Can we avoid using Graphical Views (with explicit joins) and still access all necessary attributes for calculated logic?

Is there a way to avoid date attributes and to assume the period start as the first time there's activity? and the lost customer would be the last activity of a "non active" (attribute) customer? how do I do it?

thank you

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud for planning - Change Table Function based on Filter Value
entry.content:
Hi friends,

In our planning scenario, we have several users with access to all Company Codes within the dataset. As a result, these users require the ability to view all Company Codes simultaneously, which enables the "Select All" option in the Company Code filter.

However, when a user selects "All" and then adds a new member to the dataset, the values are incorrectly distributed across all Company Codes‚Äîan invalid outcome.

Is there a scripting option to disable the "Add Member" function when "All" is selected in the Story Filter? This would serve as a useful security and quality safeguard.

Looking forward to your insights.

Based on @N1kh1l I wrote following Code. Instead of the InputControl_1 how can I adress the StoryFilter for Company Code?

if (InputControl_1.getInputControlDataSource().isAllMembersSelected()===true)
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ{
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇTable_1.setQuickActionsVisibility({addMember:false});
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ}
else if (InputControl_1.getInputControlDataSource().isAllMembersSelected()===false)
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ{
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇTable_1.setQuickActionsVisibility({addMember:true});
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ}

Since selecting "All" returns an empty value, I needed a way to detect when "All" is selected. My approach was to count the rows in a support table where only the relevant dimension is placed in the row section. With the filter set to single selection (including "All"), the number of dimension rows will either be 1 or greater than 1. This logic allows us to infer whether "All" is selected. I implemented this in the "OnResultChange" level.

This approach also works when a Story Filter is applied, as the script dynamically reacts to filter changes and still evaluates the row count accordingly.

var resultSet = Table_1.getDataSource().getResultSet();

var anzahlZeilen = resultSet.length;

if (anzahlZeilen > 1) {
    Table_1.setQuickActionsVisibility({addMember: false});
} else if (anzahlZeilen === 1) {
    Table_1.setQuickActionsVisibility({addMember: true});
}

Changing QuickAction can be used for any table. Enjoy using this code.

Kind regards,
Ismail

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity you‚Äôve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud, Artificial Intelligence, SAP Business Technology Platform, within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelor‚Äôs or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2‚Äì3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAP‚Äôs mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via üëâ SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAP‚Äôs social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

entry.title: Prevent empty version columns in table for version‚Äêrestricted measure
entry.content:
I have a story based on an Account-based model that uses multiple versions (A0, A1, A2, B0, B1, C0, D0, E10, E20, E30). In the underlying model, I‚Äôve created calculated measures that are restricted to specific versions‚Äîfor example, a measure that only applies to version D0.

Problem:
Even though the measure is correctly defined to return values only for version D0, when I add it to a table in my story, SAC still creates separate columns for every version (A0‚ÄìE30), leaving most columns empty. This results in a large number of unnecessary blank columns.

Question:
Is there a way to prevent SAC from generating empty columns for versions where the restricted measure has no data? In other words, can I force the table to show the measure only under its defined version (D0) and omit all other version columns entirely?

entry.title: How to properly connect SAC to PaPM On-Prem with the PaPM API and use SSO
entry.content:

Suffice it to say, Paul Simon knows 50 ways to leave your lover, and I have found 50 so-called solutions to my problem, but none of them work. 

Has anyone been able to do what my requirement is asking for? Again, the PaPM instance is on premise and the user wants to use multiple functions in SAC for PaPM. We can get it to work with a static user and password, but even with all the setup work completed as per several blogs, the connection will not work.

entry.title: Guidance for Adjusting Drill Limits in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for end users
entry.content:
Hi Community,

In SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), when a table exceeds the default drill limit of 500 rows or 60 columns, a warning symbol (‚ö†Ô∏è) appears. While I understand that users can manually adjust the drill limit by hovering over the warning and selecting ‚ÄúEdit Drill Limitation‚Äù, I‚Äôm looking for the best way to guide end users through this process effectively.

Specifically, I‚Äôd like to know:

  • Is there a recommended way to display a message or popup within the story or analytic application to instruct users on how to change the drill limit? need steps how to do this?
  • Can this be automated or triggered when the warning appears?
  • Are there any best practices or UI/UX suggestions for making this guidance more intuitive for business users?

Any insights, examples, or documentation links would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance,
Govardhana Rao Vegi

entry.title: How to create a measure in SAC that always shows a fixed month value regardless of the data filter
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working in SAP Analytics Cloud with an import model based on an Excel file.

I need to create a calculated measure that should always display the value of another measure restricted to a specific month (e.g., January), but it should remain visible across all months in the story, even if a date filter is applied.

Example:

  • I have a measure [Legacy Book Value Assets].

  • I want to create another measure that takes only the value of [Legacy Book Value Assets] for January 2025.

  • When I filter the story for June 2025, I still want this "January-based" measure to be displayed for every month (replicated), instead of disappearing because of the date filter.

I tried using a Restricted Measure for January, but when I change the date filter in the story, the measure goes blank.

Is there a way to define this logic directly in the model (calculated measure), so that the value for January remains visible across all months, regardless of the story filters?

Any workaround, formula example, model design best practice would be highly appreciated but please do not consider Data Action solutions.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: How to Perform 80/20 Spend Analysis on Suppliers in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I'm looking to perform a Pareto analysis in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to identify how many suppliers account for 80% of our total spend. I understand this involves using the 80/20 rule, and I‚Äôd appreciate guidance or best practices on how to implement this effectively in SAC.

 

Best Regards,

Govardhan

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud How to Aggregate a Calculated Measure to the User-Selected Date
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I need to create a calculated measure "TEST" in SAP Analytics Cloud that sums a measure from the beginning of the year up to the date selected by the user in the story. 

The base measure I am using  [Program_Gross_Investment_Income] is itself a calculated measure .

What I tried

  1. YTD Function
    YTD([Program_Gross_Investment_Income], [d/Date])
    ‚Üí Returns no values, seems not to work with calculated measures:

     

  2. LOOKUP Function
    LOOKUP([Program_Gross_Investment_Income], [d/Date] = ToPeriod("Month"))
    ‚Üí Fails with an error; LOOKUP appears unsuitable for cumulative logic.

     

  3. ITERATE Function
    ITERATE(PRIOR() + [Program_Gross_Investment_Income], [Program_Gross_Investment_Income], [d/Date].[p/DAY])
    ‚Üí Works fine but only when multiple months are selected. If only one month is filtered, it ignores previous months: 

What I need

  • Aggregate a calculated measure YTD which sums all the months before the selected one, regardless of the filter.

  • Ensure previous months are included even if only one month is selected.

Has anyone found a working approach or best practice for this? I would appriciate any suggestions or workarounds.

Many thanks in advance!

entry.title: Delete data from previous months after adding those to the targetmonth
entry.content:
Hello team,

I have a data action with the following code:

MEMBERSET [d/Date] = %SourceMonth% TO %TargetMonth%

MEMBERSET [d/CP_DI_Origem] = ("Compromissos")

DATA([d/Date] = %TargetMonth%) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(11, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(10, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(9, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(8, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(7, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(6, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(5, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(4, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(3, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(2, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = PREVIOUS(1, "MONTH", %TargetMonth%)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Date] = %TargetMonth%)

After calculating the sum for the target month, I want it to clear the values from the previous months.
Is there a way to do this in a single data action?

I tried using parameters, but I need to select multiple months from SourceMonth up to TargetMonth - 1. However, when using parameters, I'm only allowed to set granularity to single and cardinality to Leaf.

Can you help me with this?

Thank you very much,
Ganjos
